title: Synthetic Recap
body:
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) — The final buzzer sounded, but the show was far from over. All eyes in the Meadowlands arena remained fixed on one man: Jayson Williams. The New Jersey Nets’ ferocious heart had just not only dismantned the Philadelphia 76ers, 107-88, he had authored a performance for the ages, one that echoed through the rafters and into the record books.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Williams’ night. He was an unstoppable force, a whirlwind of energy that the 76ers had no answer for. When the dust settled, the stat sheet told a story of pure domination: a staggering **28 points, 26 rebounds, and 7 assists**. This was not just a double-double; it was a historic declaration.

Williams owned the painted area, hauling in rebounds with a voracious appetite that seemed to defy physics. His 26 boards were a testament to relentless hustle and sheer will, snatching possessions away from Philadelphia time and again. But he was more than just a brute force under the rim. His 28 points, many on powerful putbacks and a soft touch around the basket, kept the scoreboard ticking, while his 7 assists revealed the vision of a complete floor general.

While teammate Kendall Gill provided a stellar scoring complement with 24 points, and Sam Cassell orchestrated the offense with 15 points and 13 assists, this victory had one author. The Nets’ comprehensive win—out-rebounding, out-assisting, and simply out-working their rivals—was a direct extension of Williams’ monumental will.

On this night in 1998, Jayson Williams didn’t just play a game of basketball. He staged a masterclass, a 48-minute tour de force that reminded everyone why the sport is so captivating. It was a performance so colossal, so complete, that the final score felt almost secondary to the legend born on the court.
